questions.text: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.

During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of the dorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsal duct usually persists as an accessory duct.

In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum (pancreas divisum). Pancreatic drainage is accomplished mainly through the accessory papilla.

Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, the pancreas divisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to the development of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of pancreatic divisum?

choices.text: Pancreatojejunostomy is also known as Puestow's procedure
ERCP is more advantageous than MRCP for the diagnosis

questions.solution:
MRCP is more advantageous than ERCP in diagnosing pancreatic divisum. This is because, MRCP can delineate the entire dorsal pancreatic duct, whereas ERCP can assess only the ventral duct on cannulation of the major duodenal papilla.

The diagnosis of pancreatic divisum can also be made by EUS, or ERCP, augmented by injection of secretin if necessary.

Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla relieve the symptoms. Surgical intervention may involve sphincteroplasty, pancreatojejunostomy (Puestow procedure), or even resection of the pancreatic head.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrent non-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed second portion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. Which of the following statements is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
MRCP is the gold standard investigation

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an MRCP.

The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome.

Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. 

Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.

The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with sudden onset abdominal pain in the epigastric region radiating to the back. The pain relieves on leaning forwards. X-ray abdomen shows no gas under the diaphragm. Elevated amylase levels and total WBC count are seen. Which of the following signs are likely to be present in this condition?
  1. Fox sign
  2. Rovsing sign
  3. Cullen's sign
  4. Aaron sign
  5. Grey Turner sign
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Rovsing sign and Aaron sign are seen in acute appendicitis.

Rovsing sign: Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant. 

Aaron sign: Pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point.

In severe acute pancreatitis, the injured pancreas releases pancreatic enzymes that cause fat necrosis and inflammation, occasionally resulting in peri-pancreatic bleeding. The resulting fluid collection can travel via an anatomical defect of the transversalis fascia. This accumulates at various sites and shows discoloration of the skin.

Cullen's sign: If the blood diffuses from the retroperitoneum along with the gastrohepatic and falciform ligaments to the umbilicus, it results in bluish discoloration around the umbilicus

Grey Turner sign: If the blood diffuses from the posterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of the quadratus lumborum muscle, it results in bluish discoloration of the flanks

Fox sign: Pooling of retroperitoneal hemorrhage at the inguinal ligament shows discoloration below the inguinal ligament

Bryant sign: Pooling of blood at the scrotum

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

questions.text: What is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is the presence of gallstones (50-70%). The second most common cause is alcohol abuse (25%).

Causes of acute pancreatitis: (Mnemonic: I GET SMASHED)

  • I – Idiopathic
  • G – Gallstones
  • E – Ethanol
  • T – Trauma
  • S – Steroids
  • M – Mumps, malignancy (pancreatic cancer)
  • A – Autoimmune
  • S – Scorpion sting
  • H – Hypercalcemia, hypertriglyceridemia (Usually more than 1000 mg/dL)
  • E – Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • D – Drugs

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

questions.text:
A patient presenting with acute abdomen was found to have elevated serum amylase levels. Which of the following should be part of your differential diagnosis?
  1. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  2. Abdominal aortic aneurysm
  3. Cholecystitis
  4. Diabetic ketoacidosis
  5. Intestinal obstruction
questions.solution:
All the above conditions should be part of the differential diagnosis in patients with acute abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels.

Conditions associated with elevated serum amylase levels:

  • Burns
  • Pregnancy
  • Pancreatitis
  • Cholecystitis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Renal failure
  • Renal transplantation
  • Chronic liver disease
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Drugs like morphine
  • Salivary gland involvement: mumps, calculus, maxillofacial surgery
  • Tumors of the lungs, esophagus, breast, or ovary (LEBO)

Related Pearl: Causes of Hyperamylasemia

  • Pancreatic pseudocyst
  • Ascites caused by pancreatic duct disruption
  • Pancreatic necrosis, trauma, carcinoma

    • Calculus
    • Irradiation sialadenitis
    • Maxillofacial surgery
  • CA lung/esophagus/breast/ovary

questions.text: All of the following derangements can be expected in a patient with acute pancreatitis except:
questions.solution:
Acute pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

The pancreatic enzymes cause autodigestion of the mesenteric fat leading to the release of free fatty acids. These free fatty acids combine with calcium to form calcium salts, causing low levels of circulating calcium.

Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute pancreatitis. 

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Alvarado scoring is used in acute appendicitis, not acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: All of the following parameters will be included in the assessment of acute pancreatitis using Ranson's criteria, except:
questions.solution:
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson’s criteria, not 250 IU/L.

questions.text: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of:
questions.solution:
Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis.

Revised atlanta classification:

Mild Acute Pancreatitis

  • No organ failure
  • No local or systemic complications

Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or

  • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours) – Single organ or multiorgan

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.solution:
A gasless abdomen is an X-ray feature that can be seen in acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen.

Common causes of gasless abdomen include:

  • High obstruction: gastric outlet obstruction, congenital atresia
  • Small bowel obstruction 
  • Bowel ischemia
  • Ascites
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Gastroenteritis
  • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement
  • Post-surgery following total colectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior resection
  • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults

Note: In intussusception, an X-ray shows small bowel obstruction, a mass, and a paucity of gas in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The image shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the left side. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the colon cut-off sign.

All the other options mentioned above are also seen in acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding usage of the contrast-enhanced CT scan in cases of acute pancreatitis?

choices.text: It is the investigation of choice
It should be done within 72 hours from the onset of symptoms
Balthazar criteria is used to stage the severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan
Signs of sepsis is an indication for CT scan

questions.solution:
The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis.

A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice in acute pancreatitis. However, it is not performed in all cases of pancreatitis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis:

  • Diagnostic uncertainty
  • In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis
  • In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration
  • When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a pseudoaneurysm

 The image below is a CT scan from a patient with acute exudative pancreatitis.

 

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

Balthazar Score
Balthazar Grade Appearance on CT CT Grade Points
Grade A Normal CT 0 Points
Grade B Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 1 Point
Grade C Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation  2 Points
Grade D  Fluid collection in a single location 3 Points
Grade E Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas 4 Points

 

Necrosis Score  
Necrosis Percentage CT grade points
No necrosis 0 points
0 to 30% necrosis 2 points
30 to 50% necrosis 4 points
Over 50% necrosis 6 points

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points. 

CTSI score 0-3: Mild pancreatitis

CTSI score 4-6: Moderate pancreatitis

CTSI score 7-10: Severe pancreatitis

questions.text: A patient with acute pancreatitis underwent a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. CT scan shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas without necrosis. What will be the CT severity index of the patient?
questions.solution:
The CT severity index (CTSI) of this patient will be 1.

The CT severity index for grading of acute pancreatitis is determined as the sum of two scores:

  • Balthazar score: grading of pancreatitis 
  • Necrosis score: grading of the extent of pancreatic necrosis

The Balthazar score for diffuse enlargement of the pancreas is 1. Since there is no necrosis, the necrosis score of the patient is zero. Hence the CTSI of this patient is 1.

questions.text: When will you use the SOFA score in a patient with acute pancreatitis?

choices.text: To assess the need for surgery
In cases of pancreatic abscess formation
To assess the length of hospital stay

questions.solution:
The Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score is used to assess organ failure in acute pancreatitis. The three organ systems most frequently involved are the cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. Multiple organ failures are said to exist when 2 or more organs register 2 or more points on these scoring systems.

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg)
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths per min)
  • Altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15)

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with a 1-day history of sudden onset of severe abdominal pain with radiation to the back. He gives a history of binge drinking on the night prior to his symptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable and there is no sign of organ impairment. His serum amylase level is 500 U/L ( normal: 23–85 U/L) and lipase level is 1100 U/L (normal: 10-140 U/L). Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: CECT abdomen is almost always necessary to establish the diagnosis
CT should be performed 72 hours after the onset of symptoms to assess complications
Modified marshall scoring system can be used to assess the severity of organ failure
Early initiation of enteral nutrition is beneficial for overall improvement of prognosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with characteristic lab findings is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. CECT abdomen is not always necessary to diagnose acute pancreatitis. 
According to the revised Atlanta classification, acute pancreatitis is clinically defined by at least the first two of three features:

  1. abdominal pain suggestive of pancreatitis (epigastric pain often radiating to the back),
  2. serum amylase and lipase levels ≥ 3 times normal (imaging is to be used if the elevated values are less than 3 times normal); and
  3. characteristic imaging findings on CT, magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, or transabdominal ultrasonographic (US) studies.   

 If acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of the first two criteria with no systemic sign of severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome or persistent organ failure, contrast material–enhanced CT may not be necessary for determining patient care.

Option B: The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis are

  • Diagnostic uncertainty
  • In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis
  • In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration
  • When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a pseudoaneurysm

Option C: For severe acute pancreatitis with systemic inflammatory response syndrome and possible organ impairment, the modified marshall scoring can be used to assess the severity of organ failure. It includes respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal systems scores. A score of more than 2 for any organs indicates organ failure. Revised Atlanta classification recommends the modified Marshall scoring system as the main tool in determining organ failure.

Option D: Current evidence confirms that the administration of enteral nutrition is beneficial for the treatment of severe acute pancreatitis. Enteral feeding reduces mortality, infectious complications, and multiorgan failure. In terms of the timing of enteral nutritional support, relatively early administration within 48 or 72 h of hospital admission is suggested.

questions.text: A patient with pancreatitis is likely to develop all of the following vascular complications, except:
questions.solution:
Mesenteric artery thrombosis is unlikely in patients with acute pancreatitis.

The most common vascular complication following acute pancreatitis is arterial pseudoaneurysm.

Related Pearl: Vascular complications of pancreatitis

Arterial pseudoaneurysm:

  • It is caused by damage to the vessel wall by pancreatic elastase
  • The most common vessel affected is the splenic artery, but the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), cystic artery, and gastroduodenal artery (GDA) may also be affected
  • Spontaneous rupture results in massive bleeding
  • Clinical manifestations include sudden onset of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension.
  • CT angiography is the investigation of choice
  • Treatment
    • Arterial embolization
    • Ligation of the affected vessel in refrac­tory cases

Vascular thrombosis:

  • The vessel usually affected is the splenic vein, but in severe cases, it can extend into the portal venous system
  • Clinical features include splenomegaly, gastric varices, and splenic vein occlusion
  • Treatment:
    • Mostly conservative
    • Throm­bolytics in the acute early phase

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with complaints of progressive abdominal distension. His past history is significant for acute pancreatitis which was managed by supportive care. USG abdomen showed peri-pancreatic ascitic fluid collection. A large volume paracentesis (LVP) was performed. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: The ascitic fluid will be low in protein.
Amylase levels in the fluid are raised.
Somatostatin will help in decreasing secretion.

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pancreatic ascites. The pancreatic ascitic fluid is rich in enzymes, and not low in protein.

Pancreatic ascites occurs due to the disruption of the pancreatic duct. It presents with significant abdominal distention, with free intra-abdominal fluid.

Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipase levels.

Treatment involves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding and administration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdomi­nal drainage combined with the endoscopic placement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done.

If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure of the proxi­mal stump is done.

questions.text: A young lady presents with acute epigastric pain and vomiting. She also gives a history of pain and swelling over the right parotid gland for 3 days. USG abdomen reveals peripancreatic ascitic fluid collection. Which of the following is not true about the fluid collection?

choices.text: It is not associated with fibrous wall
The most common vessel involved is the splenic artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis caused due to mumps. Hemosuccus pancreaticus in acute pancreatitis is not associated with ascites.

Hemosuccus pancreaticus is due to the erosion of the wall of the pancreatic pseudocyst into the splenic artery forming a direct communication. It presents with abdominal pain and upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, without ascites.

In contrast to pseudocysts and cystic neoplasias of the pancreas, fluid collections are not surrounded or encased by epithelium or fibrotic capsules.

Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipase levels.

Most fluid collections will be spontaneously reabsorbed by the peritoneum. Treatment involves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding and administration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdomi­nal drainage combined with the endoscopic placement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done.

If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure of the proxi­mal stump is done.

questions.text: A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following binge drinking. 7-days post-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBC count of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings are suggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage.

A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity to the pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Elevated white blood cell count
  • Abdominal pain

Contrast-enhanced CT scan and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosis and abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection.

Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imaging guidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be part of the management plan of patients with infected pancreatic necrosis?
questions.solution:
Infected pancreatic necrosis should not be managed conservatively with antibiotics alone because of the high risk of multiorgan failure and death.

CT scan has to be performed in patients with severe acute pancreatitis, organ failure, sepsis, and in patients with clinical deterioration despite the treatment:

  • If the CT scan shows the presence of sterile pancreatic necrosis medical management is recommended.
  • If the CT scan shows the presence of necrosis with evidence of infection, then ultrasound or CT-guided aspiration of the fluid has to be done and the fluid is sent for staining and culture. 

Infected pancreatic necrosis is treated by the administration of intravenous antibiotics (preferably carbapenems) and percutaneous drainage of the infected fluid. Pancreatic necrosectomy is be considered in the patients if the clinical condition worsens despite percutaneous drainage.

questions.text: Regarding the revised Atlanta classification for morphologic stages of acute pancreatitis, which of the following is not true?

choices.text: Acute necrotic collection is non-encapsulated necrosis within 4 weeks of onset
Acute peripancreatic fluid collection can be seen in interstitial edematous pancreatitis
Pancreatic pseudocyst can be seen in necrotizing pancreatitis
Collection that contains non-liquefied material is more likely to become infected

questions.solution:
Pancreatic pseudocyst is seen as a sequela of interstitial edematous pancreatitis, which is a non-necrotic collection. Necrotizing pancreatitis usually leads to acute necrotic collection (ANC) and walled-off necrosis (on encapsulation of ANC).

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation.

  • IEP - Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis
    • APFC - Acute Peripancreatic Fluid Collection:
      Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks
    • Pancreatic pseudocyst: 
      Non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
  • Necrotising Pancreatitis
    • ANC - Acute Necrotic Collection:
      Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks
    • WON - Walled-Off Necrosis:
      Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
Duration since onset IEP Necrotizing pancreatitis

ANC, APFC, WON, and pancreatic pseudocysts can be infected or non-infected. Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl was rushed to the casualty after she was injured by a bicycle’s handlebar in the abdomen. She complains of severe epigastric pain. On examination, bruises are seen in the epigastrium. Her CT scan is given below. Which of the following statements is false about her condition?

choices.text: Distal pancreatectomy will be the definitive management.
Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a handlebar injury and the CT scan showing transection of the body of the pancreas are suggestive pancreatic injury. Plasma amylase levels are not sensitive in pancreatic injuries.

The most common mechanism of pancreatic injury in children is blunt trauma (because of the decreased amount of fat and incomplete protection of the rib cage). In adults, penetrating injuries are the most common cause. Involvement of other organs is also likely to be seen. 

Direct compression of the epigastrium against the vertebral column and a blunt object (handlebar) is typically seen after bicycle injuries. The most common segment of the pancreas affected is the body. 

Patients usually present with epigastric pain. In some cases, a delayed presentation may be due to leakage of pancreatic fluids.

The modality of choice is the CT scan of the abdomen. If there is doubt about duct disruption, an urgent ERCP or MRCP should be done.

Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted. A damage control procedure with packing and drainage should be performed initially and the patient referred for definitive surgery after stabilization. 

Definitive management includes:

  • Distal pancreatectomy - If the body or tail is involved
  • External drainage - If the head of the pancreas is involved 
  • Pancreatoduodenectomy - If the pancreatic head and duodenum is involved
